name.value: The Great Battles of Alexander: Macedonian Art of War

item.description:
The Great Battles of Alexander - Macedonian Art of War Expanded Deluxe Edition (2014, Fourth Printing) is the first volume of the multi-volume counters-on-hexagons famous wargame Great Battles of History series, with the latest and updated 5th Edition game rules made by Mark Herman & Richard Berg.

Available Battles (19 in total):

 Scenario Book (12):
 Erigon Valley (358 BC)
 Crocus Fields (352 BC)
 Chaeronea (338 BC)
 Lyginus (335 BC)
 Pelium (355 BC)
 Granicus (334 BC)
 Issus (333 BC)
 Gaugamela (331 BC)
 Crossing the Jaxartes (329 BC)
 Samarkand (329/328 BC)
 Arigaeum (327 BC)
 Hydaspes (326 BC)
 
 Phalanx Module (2):
 Sellasia (221 BC)
 Mantinea (207 BC)
 
 Diadochoi Module (4):
 Paraetacene (317 BC)
 Gabiene (316 BC)
 Gaza (312 BC)
 Ipsus (301 BC)
 
 Raphia Module (1):
 Raphia (217 BC)
 




Game Scale Details:
Unit: 100 men per unit strength point
Time: 20 minutes per game turn
Map: 70 yards per hexagon

item.description:
User summary:

Dreamstarter is a simultaneous action selection investment card game.

Players have a hand of money cards numbered between 0 and 12. Each round, a venture card is drawn with a specific difficulty. Each player invests a hidden amount, which is then turned up, and dice rolled to see if the venture succeeds, with a higher probability if enough people invested. If the venture succeeds, each investor gains a certain amoung of VP. It takes one round for the used investment cards to return to the hand of the players, and even longer if the venture failed. Event cards throws in other unexpected factors in the game.

Most VP at the end wins.

All pirates of the Seven Seas are looking for the Treasure Island, where Barbarosa, the infamous pirate, hid his precious treasure! Are you ready for this incredible voyage? You'll need courage and a bit of luck!

L'Isola del Tesoro is a great adventure game with pirates, ships and treasures. It is a game for the whole family, easy to learn, with a fast gameplay and two bonuses for the bravest pirates.

L'Isola del Tesoro is a basic roll and move game, where you are trying to get from the Start tile to the Treasure Island, progressing through all the Sea tiles placed in a line. On your turn, you roll the six-sided die and move as many spaces as the result of the roll. You flip the tile where you land and apply any effect indicated (move forward one space, move to the tile where stands the last ship, skip your turn...). The first player to reach the Treasure Island wins the game.

The Monster tiles are used to block your progression. When you cross one, you must stop, flip it and stop your turn. On the following turn, you roll the die to try to beat the monster. Whoever beats the monster gets the tile, which doesn't give any advantage.

Rondo is a game for 2-4 Players, with a rotary disk on the game board.

The Rotary disk is transparent. Except the start and end fields the whole way with all fields are covered with this disk.
The path on the board is seperated in 2 concentric circles, with the private starts at the outside and the private destinations in the middle.

The base rule is a simple, role the die and move one of your four pawns in direction of your private destination.
The pawns have 2 sizes. If your pawn is larger or equal as the pawn before it, you can pass it with a high die number.
If your pawn is smaller than the pawns on your way you have to stay behind it.

Each pawn can throw out each opponents pawn if the pawn reaches exact the position of it. This is independent of their size. 
Some fields are marked. If a pawn hits one of the marked fields, the disk is turned with all pawns on it. The new position is reached, when the players pawn is on the next marked field.
There are only some single links between the circles and only 1 link from the inner circle to your Destination.

Therefor the rotation of all pawns may move them nearer to the destination or they have to run a full round again because they were moved on the wrong side of the link.

The Tabletop Edition has a variant box cover and includes the Felicia Day and Kodiak Colby promotional characters.

Game description from the publisher:

"Crossroads" is a new series from Plaid Hat Games that tests a group of survivors' ability to work together and stay alive while facing crises and challenges from both outside and inside.

Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game, the first game in this series, puts 2-5 players in a small, weakened colony of survivors in a world where most of humanity is either dead or diseased, flesh-craving monsters. Each player leads a faction of survivors with dozens of different characters in the game.

Dead of Winter is a meta-cooperative psychological survival game. This means players are working together toward one common victory condition — but for each individual player to achieve victory, he must also complete his personal secret objective. This secret objective could relate to a psychological tick that's fairly harmless to most others in the colony, a dangerous obsession that could put the main objective at risk, a desire for sabotage of the main mission, or (worst of all) vengeance against the colony! Certain games could end with all players winning, some winning and some losing, or all players losing. Work toward the group's goal, but don't get walked all over by a loudmouth who's looking out only for his own interests!

Dead of Winter is an experience that can be accomplished only through the medium of tabletop games. It's a story-centric game about surviving through a harsh winter in an apocalyptic world. The survivors are all dealing with their own psychological imperatives, but must still find a way to work together to fight off outside threats, resolve crises, find food and supplies, and keep the colony's morale up.

Dead of Winter has players making frequent, difficult, heavily- thematic, wildly-varying decisions that often have them deciding between what is best for the colony and what is best for themselves.

item.description: In Sunken Treasure, the player's deep sea diver has to leave the salvage ship to recover a gold bar from a chest at the bottom of the sea. The player must then return the gold bar to the salvage ship.

This game is based on the Disney movie Aladdin.

Each player has his own Aladdin figure in his color. The players try as fast as possible to get to the palace of the Sultan trying to get the most valuable treasures on their way.

The movement of the figures is card driven. Player plays 1 card from 2 each round and gets after the action is done a new card.

There are the following card types

 Aladdin cards: for moving 1 to 5 fields (exact)
 Carpet cards: moving to the next carpet field.
 Dschafar cards: 1 opponent player has to pause.




If the card played has the same color as the last on the trash pile. The player can play an additional card.

There are Special fields (so called wonder caves). If a figure passes it, he gets a treasure Card without looking on the value.
If he hits the field. The player is allowed to check the value and to decide if he wants this or a blind new one.

Each player has 3 different wishes, he is allowed to use in his turn (1 Opponent 6 fields back, all opponents back 1 to 3 fields, himself 4 fields in front) Maximum 1 wish/turn.

In the palace the player can choose 1 of 4 open treasures (value 1-4) if he is the first. Otherwise one of the remaining

Game Ends when all figures are in the palace. The player with the most valuable treasures gets Jasmin as his wife and wins the game. If 2 have equal treasures the first arrived player wins.

Match'n'Turn is a very special lotto!

You must match the images on the tiles with those on your board. It seems simple, but the objects to look for keep changing!

You have to look carefully to gather the most tiles.

name.value: Abbatti, Combatti e Arraffa il Malloppo

item.description:
Take to the high seas as the captain of your very own pirate ship. Seek out valuable merchant ships and raid them for their goods! Hire new crew, upgrade your ship, and give your treasure to the Pirate King for fame and glory!

Rattle, Battle, Grab the Loot takes the fun of rolling dice and combines it with a rich scenario deck to make each game play differently. Each round, the players battle it out with merchant vessels and other ships, trying to grab as much loot as possible. One player takes dice from all the players, rattles them in their hand, then tosses them into the game box to resolve the battle. Where your dice land in the box, in addition to the symbols rolled, determines the results of the battle, then players claim their loot. Players may now return to port to upgrade their ship, hire new crew, or give their goods to the Pirate King for his favor.

When upgrading their ship, players use physical pieces to assemble their vessel, making each ship look different. In the box are dozens of punchboard pieces to customize your ship. In addition to common items and crew members, there will be unique item upgrades and crew that can make your ship stand out among the crowd!

At the end of the game, the player who earned the most favor from the Pirate King wins!

item.description:
This are 2 games in 1 box: Allegro & Zet

For both games: Each player has figures and stones which he moves by dice rolling.
There are possibilities to throw out figures or Stones.
Stones can block the movement of opponent's figures

Allegro:
Start field of the stones is in the middle of the plan. The figures start at a field at the boarder.
On Players turn he moves 1 figur or stone the sum of number of the 2 rolled dice. 
Stones can throw out other stones and other figures. They can cross over figures and stones.
Figures can throw out figures and stones but figures are not allowed to pass by stones. Figures are allowed to pass by other figures. 
The player whose figures are first on his stones start place and additional the Stones on the figures start place has won.

Zet:
All Stones and figures start at the same place. 2 dice are rolled. The Player chooses 2 Stones or 1 Stone and 1 figure and moves each for the number of 1 of the dice.
Stones are placed on other Stones if they reach exact the same place.
Stones are blocking Stones below them. Figures are also blocking stones below. Figures on stones are save (cannot be thrown out).
Figures throw out other figures if they reach the same place. 
Figures and stones are allowed to pass by other figures and stones.
Player whose figures and stones are first on the Destination field wins.

name.value: TORNADO 1-2-3-Im Sausewind, wir sind gespannt, wer heut gewinnt

item.description:
Each Player has four figures and tries to get first all of the to the centre in the middle of the circle shaped game board.

The movement is dice driven.
If the 2 dice show a double the transparent disk covering the whole gameboard is rotated to the next mark on the board, before the a figure is moved.
All figures are turned around with this disk move.
Due to the fact that the 7 circular paths have gaps some figures may have after the turn a position outside the path.
These have to start at the start field at the boarder again.
Opponet figures can be thrown out by coming exact on their position.
Movement can be done in both directions.

A competitive deck-trashing game for 2-5 players by Florian Woo.

Each player plays a famous Mind Master. These people have telepathic abilities, which allow them to read the minds of others and exchange and extract memories from there.

Every year, the greatest of these Mind Masters meet in a battle for sanity. During these tournaments, they try to bring the most precious memories of each opponent into the foreground, so that they can access and delete these thoughts forever. Only the ones who keep these hidden until the end will stay sane.

Mind Masters is a competitive card game, where each player has an identical 40 cards deck at the beginning. Inside these decks, there a five "Precious Memory" cards, which each player has to protect. They will play cards forcing the others to discard or even trash cards, to finally remove all of their "Precious Memories". Therefore, the deck gets thinner and thinner over game play. The last player keeping at least one of his "Precious Memories" wins.

This game was created for the March 2015 24h design contest at BGG (theme: confusion).

Box includes 2 Games:
Glückspilz (2-4 players): Looks like Pachisi but with dice instead of pawns.
Master Mix (2 players): Player has to place dice on a chess board.

Each player has 45 stones of his Color.
On a player's turn, he rolls a special die. The die sides show the numbers 1-3, card symbol and star.
Rolling a number allows the player to place this number of Stones.
When rolling a card, the player takes a card and tries to fullfill it (e.g. build a special form with his stones)


 remove 1 Stone.


In most cases placing stones is only allowed if they are neighboard to each other and to previous placed of the same Color.
Game ends when no field is empty or if one Player has placed all his Stones. The Player who placed the most stones wins the game.
Cover description in 3 languages. The box contains only German rules.
In King of Tiger Heart, players represent knights of the kingdom who are trying to regain control of the country — well, all but one of them are as a traitor lurks amongst the knights...

In 2396, with an invading force surrounding the Earth, different army troops have had genetic implants to grant them the characteristics of a particular animal in order to aid them on missions against this force.

Rabbit Project is a role-playing card game in one player takes the role of the invading Overlord and 1-3 players comprise the rabbit team and work to complete missions with limited supplies available to them.

A game of deduction and bluffing with eleven playing cards, JT98765432A, and two players.

One secret card is laid face-down in the middle of the table. The rest are dealt between the players. The goal is to guess the secret card. A guess ends the game and determines the winner, according to whether the guess was correct or not.

Players take turns either asking the other if s/he has a given card or making a guess. When asked about a card, the opponent must answer truthfully and lay it face up if the card was held. A player may ask the opponent about a card s/he holds, in which case, s/he will lay it face up on his/her next turn. (The idea is that this bluff might make the opponent make an incorrect guess.)

Outer Box Description:
In this hilarious game, players draw cards and match pairs. But beware! If the skunk sneaks into your hand, you lose the game. The cards are filled with funny jokes and fun animal facts to share around the campfire.

Setup: Shuffle the Deck. Deal out the cards one at a time to all of the players. Some players may get an extra card. Cards in players hand are always kept hidden from other players. Any cards making pairs are laid down in front of players at this time. Compass cards are not used at this time.

Game Play: The player to the left of the dealer draws one card from the dealers hand. If a pair is made, the pair is laid down immediately. The person now offers cards to the player on his/her left.

Compass Cards: The compass cards are "reverse" cards. If the person who is about to draw holds a compass card, he/she may place it at the center of the table, and then draw a card from the player on his/her opposite side. The order of offering cards reverses until another compass card is played. The game play direction may change up to 3 times as each compass card may only be used once. If a player draws a compass card from another player, it cannot be used until his/her next turn. When there are two players, a player may play a reverse card instead of drawing.

Be My Valentine is a love decipher for more-than-friendly encounters. The players can game themselves into happiness through letter delivery to gauge whether the messages you are receiving from the guy who likes you. Basically, the players can get/lose love points via a series of love actions— sending letters sending letters, confessing love or being a matchmaker. After the end of the game, the player(s) with the most love points is the best lover and wins the game!

item.description:
In Stratos, players assume the role of rival tribes vying for control of a newly discovered land. Players succeed in their quest by hiring and developing groups of characters that can accumulate resources and exercise unique abilities. Players collect resources from the game board through character actions and spend them to hire new characters and advance their tribe.

Stratos has 5 character classes, each serving a distinct function. The 5 classes and their (promoted forms) are the Peasant (Cultivator), Archer (Marksman), Soldier (Knight), Explorer (Swashbuckler) and Mage (Sorcerer). Each promoted class gains expanded abilities compared to its original version. Enhanced abilities include greater attacks (Knight vs. Soldier), access to stronger spells (Sorcerer vs. Mage), improved resource harvesting (Cultivator vs. Peasant), expanded movement (Swashbuckler vs. Explorer) and increased attack accuracy (Marksman vs. Archer). Characters move from space to space on a tile-based board which can be arranged randomly or according to set maps. Each character can perform up to 2 unique actions per turn with movement being a repeatable action. Available character actions (dependent on class) include Harvest, Travel, Search, Attack, Shoot, Defend, Cast and Use.

Points are awarded by defeating characters, casting unique spells, discovering treasures, hoarding resources, promoting characters and occupying key map locations.

The first player to reach a pre-determined number of Prosperity points (default 10) is declared the winner.

Stratos is a product of Board and Tale Games Inc., a Canadian boardgame publisher based in Hamilton, Ontario.

item.description: Ä°htilal ("Revolution") is a 2 player strategy board game where the objective is to hold power over the people and the institutions of 1950 to 1980s Turkey. The players choose between centre-left or centre-right. Meanwhile the incidents that shaped the Turkish history appear as "Event Cards" and steer the game, sometimes foiling your plans, sometimes working in your favor. The players try to manage independent political organizations, infiltrate institutions such as the army and the police and make place for themselves on the board as well, which represents various cities and regions. The game takes about 1 hour from start to finish including setup.

item.description:
Play as a zombie trying to survive encounters with humans in this quick and easy card game.

Each player has a zombie composed of five body part cards which can be gained or lost depending on the outcome of combat with humans. The last player with at least a zombie head remaining is the winner.

Fight back, play "even more dead." or recruit help from other players to ensure your undead survival.

name.value: Duel Bots Duel Pack: Galaxy Sword

item.description:
Rocket Fist! Form Galaxy Sword! Omicron Torpedo, fire! Giant robots battle in the style of your favorite Japanese cartoons.

Duel Bots is a card game that lets you design your own deck, load up a giant robot with high-tech components and devastating weapons, then duel head-to-head or in a multi-player death-match.

Duel packs contain two pre-constructed decks. The decks in Galaxy Sword are designed for new players to learn the game. Once you're familiar with the rules the cards can be used alone or with other duel packs to design your own custom deck.

-- Game play summary --

Design your own deck of 32 cards or use a pre-constructed deck from the duel pack. There are three type of cards: components (such as weapons or other gear), resources (which focus on hand management) and damage cards. Damage cards go in a separate pile and you draw them when your robot takes damage. When your damage pile is empty, you lose.

Each turn you may put one component into play from your hand into one of 7 available slots. This sets the pace of the game. Components get more powerful as the game goes on: Tier I components can be played right away but aren't very powerful. You must have 3 components on the table to play a more powerful Tier II component. When 6 of the 7 slots are filled you can play your signature component. Each deck has exactly one signature component, and once they start hitting the table the game will end soon. This follows with the giant robot theme, where mega-weapons tend to decide the battle after some back and forth with smaller attacks.

Damage cards first go into available component slots; you can't play a new component into a damaged slot. You may also put damage on a component on the table, which keeps you from using that component until the damage is removed. Some cards let you move damage to the discard pile where it will eventually cycle back into your hand, so that's just a temporary fix. If instead you pay the cost listed on the damage card you can remove it from the game. There are 5 different kinds of damage with 5 different costs, so choosing compatible damage cards is an important part of deck design. You also choose how many damage cards to use (8 to 12) but the total is always 32 cards, so choosing more "hit points" reduces your available number of components and resource cards.

The game has elements that limit the luck factor present in all card games. Certain resources let you choose cards from your discard pile, others from your draw pile. The small deck size ensures you will see your whole draw pile several times each game. (The discard pile shuffles to form a new draw pile when it's exhausted.) Luck plays a factor in which components come out first and in occasionally finding yourself without a component to play which can put you a turn behind.

link.value: Duel Bots Duel Pack: Crimson Spear

item.description:
Players try to bring their population to prosperity by gaining the blessings of the olympian gods!
The game uses dice to track population size and a secret bidding mechanism for gaining the god's blessings.
It's a fun mix of some careful planning and scheming but as always, when gods are involved, things can often go horribly wrong and get a bit chaotic!

Overview: In this game players take control of a population (=points, represented by dice) and compete with other players for the favours of gods in hope of being the first player to advance their population to 15 (20 for a longer game, 12 for a shorter game) points and thereby win the game.

Gameplay:
The game is played in several rounds divided into Phases, the „worship phase“ and the „blessing phase“. 
During the "worship phase", players play their offering cards on the gods in rounds of secret bidding.
Then in the "blessing phase", the gods are checked in sequence for which players played offering cards on them. The player to have played the highest card receives the "major blessing", all other players to have played any cards with a value greater than 0 receive the "lesser blessing".
blessings can have all kinds of effects, ranging form players directly gaining points by gaining dice or adding points to their dice, but also performing actions like stealing other player's dice or exchanging dice with other players.
When all god's blessings have been resolved play continues with the next round of bidding.

Outwit your fellow swashbucklers to claim the treasures hidden in the Cove! the blood seal which lies over the entrance to the Kraken's lair requires items which are identical in nature.

Kraken's Cove is a social Bluffing game inspired by the prisoner's dilemma. it is designed for 4 to 8 players and lasts about 20 minutes.

Treasure cards are placed facedown for the amount of players in the game. each player starts the day with two facedown cards of stolen goods, these can come in many forms from being magical elements, precious gems and sometimes just everyday things such as grass. players must aim to get identical items so that they may access the treasures and score Victory points in the form of Coins.

on their turn players will trade one of the two item cards they have with another player, this is done facedown and both players must agree to the trade. you can be as honest or as dishonest as you like, keep in mind players are after what you may or may not have so keep your wits about you and suss out the liars.

When you have an identical pair you may enter the lair which the kraken sleeps, you may now secretly look at a facedown treasure card. you may now choose to take either take this card or look at another one, the second card however must be taken. the treasure cards have point values on aswell as curses and items which carry bonuses. once all but one of the treasures have been taken all players must flip over their cards and score their winnings.

The player who collects the most coins (victory points) over a period of 7 weeks (rounds) will go home the victor!

name.value: Duel Bots Duel Pack: Crimson Spear

item.description:
Rocket Fist! Form Galaxy Sword! Omicron Torpedo, fire! Giant robots battle in the style of your favorite Japanese cartoons.

Duel Bots is a card game that lets you design a custom deck, load up your giant robot with high-tech components and devastating weapons, then duel head-to-head or in a multi-player death-match.

Duel packs contain two pre-constructed decks. Mix and match the cards to build hundreds of possible custom decks. Compatible with Galaxy Sword and all Duel Bots duel packs.

-- Game play summary --

Design your own deck of 32 cards or use a pre-constructed deck from the duel pack. There are three type of cards: components (such as weapons or other gear), resources (which focus on hand management) and damage cards. Damage cards go in a separate pile and you draw them when your robot takes damage. When your damage pile is empty, you lose.

Each turn you may put one component into play from your hand into one of 7 available slots. This sets the pace of the game. Components get more powerful as the game goes on: Tier I components can be played right away but aren't very powerful. You must have 3 components on the table to play a more powerful Tier II component. When 6 of the 7 slots are filled you can play your signature component. Each deck has exactly one signature component, and once they start hitting the table the game will end soon. This follows with the giant robot theme, where mega-weapons tend to decide the battle after some back and forth with smaller attacks.

Damage cards first go into available component slots; you can't play a new component into a damaged slot. You may also put damage on a component on the table, which keeps you from using that component until the damage is removed. Some cards let you move damage to the discard pile where it will eventually cycle back into your hand, so that's just a temporary fix. One card (Repair Bot) moves damage back into your damage pile at the cost of some resources, but in many cases you will need to pay the cost listed on the damage card to remove it from the game. There are 5 different kinds of damage with 5 different costs, so choosing compatible damage cards is an important part of deck design. You also choose how many damage cards to use (8 to 12) but the total is always 32 cards, so choosing more "hit points" reduces your available number of components and resource cards.

The game has elements that limit the luck factor present in all card games. Certain resources let you choose cards from your discard pile, others from your draw pile. The small deck size ensures you will see your whole draw pile several times each game. (The discard pile shuffles to form a new draw pile when it's exhausted.) Luck plays a factor in which components come out first and in occasionally finding yourself without a component to play which can put you a turn behind.

link.value: Duel Bots Duel Pack: Galaxy Sword

item.description: In ã²ã¨ã²ã‚‰ (Hitohira), players take turns drawing cherry blossoms from a bag, drawing up to three times but possibly being punished in the process. Players can use these blossoms for special abilities, and they can also place them in front of or behind their screen. At the end of the game, a player's score is based on all the blossoms they have.

link.value: The Legend of the Cherry Tree that Blossoms Every Ten Years

item.description:
The objective of El Plan, tú decides is to be the player with most innovate business ideas after twelve rounds (1 year).

In the game there are:

 3 resources: money, energy, workforce
 3 processes: logistics, production and marketing 
 3 goods: raw material, consumer goods and services




Every player will receive a business card that tells him which his strengths are. With his abilities he will be able to produce 2 of the 3 kinds of goods the game has. They produce these goods by using processes to transform resources into goods.

The boards has several places where you can get resources, have additional processes, buy and sell goods, buy cards (which give new abilities) and others.

By the end of every year players can transform 3 good, 1 of each, into an innovate idea. This can happen as many times as they like, if they have the necessary goods. Also, innovate ideas can be used as a joker for money, energy or workforce during the game.
Since each player is able to produce only 2 of the 3 goods, they will be forced to buy the third one every time they want to create an innovate idea.

item.description:
A game in which players vote their issues closer to the speaker of the house in order to increase their value before scoring. Players move issues by playing a copy from their hand to their constituency, or increase the constituency by polling and choosing an issue from the top 3 cards of the deck.

The goal of the game is to score the most over the course of 5 phases/hands. Each phase increases the number of things that are voted on by the players instead of being accomplished automatically.

Each hand ends when enough cloture motions have accumulated to force the vote. At the end of the hand, players choose a scoring method and then move on to the next phase.

You are a cat. You live in a house. You share this house with your pet Hoomin. You goal is to lavish this Hoomin with Affection while causing Mischief elsewhere in the house. The first cat to score 9 Mischief points wins the game!

---

Cantankerous Cats is a light weight, competitive card game centered around the feline propensity for mischief, cunning, and Schadenfreude. Players follow a basic Draw 3, Play 2 format with the ability to attack and interrupt other players. While a game with new players tends to be very polite and rigid; seasoned players will find a faster, brutal game that rewards clever use of hand management, probability, and cunning.

The game now features THREE ways to play: "Kitten" for families and party gamers | "Basic" for casual players | "Advanced" (formerly Standard) for tournament level play.
All rules can be downloaded here on BGG or from our website at cantankerouscats.net

This game is currently available directly from our website, Amazon.com, or Uncommon Goods.

item.description:
A trivia about wine for wine lovers.

640 questions with multiple choices in 8 themes.

Wordariffic is the party word game in which you use letter cards to make a word that best relates to a randomly chosen theme.

Each player gets 11 letter cards and tries to make a word that best relates to a random theme; the last player to put down a word loses their chance to play this round and becomes the judge. The player(s) with the longest word gets 1 point. The player with the best word (as judged by the judge) gets 3 points.

The game ends when the 32 point chips have all been handed out.

Wordariffic is a completely new standalone game influenced by party games such as Apples to Apples or Cards Against Humanity and word creation games like Scrabble or Bananagrams.

The Pits is a card game for 5 players using a pack of 54 cards, 4 normal suits of 13 cards each and 2 Jokers. The Jokers need to be distinguished as strong ("red") and weak ("black").

The cards are ranked from the strong Joker, weak Joker, all the twos, Aces, Kings etc down to the threes. There is no difference between cards of the same denomination. Jokers are completely wild and can replace any card in forming a meld. Twos are partly wild and can be used to represent a card of equal denomination to another. Twos can never be used in a single sequence.

The object of the game for all the players is to discard all their cards. The dealer initially leads and can play any meld. Players wishing to play must play the same number and type of meld, but higher ranking (e.g. a pair of fours above a pair of threes) or they may pass. It is not compulsory to play cards if a player can do so. Play continues until all players pass. The last person who played can then proceed again with any meld he chooses. If the player who played last goes out (and all the other players have passed) then the player to his left proceeds.

The dealer shuffles the cards and deals them to his left (any cutting of the cards is entirely optional and is left to the choice of the dealer). All the cards are dealt and there should be 11 cards for all players except for the dealer who has 10. In the first hand the dealer is chosen at random, usually the first person to turn up a Jack.

Pits is a corrupt version of the Chinese game ZhÄ“ng Shàngyóu.

Coin Tower is a casual abstract game that can be played for adults and children (>6 years). It's a game that have the spirit of Pong hau k’i or Tic-Tac-Toe; it's a little abstract that can be solved but that you can play with your children, or in a pub with casual gamers, because the original idea was to make it on a coaster. You need a little board game and only ten coins, that forms two towers of five coins each.

Players build two towers, five coins each tower. Each player places, per turn, one tower on an empty space on the board.

The first turn is for the player who placed the first tower on board. Per turn each player moves any tower one or two cells on the same row or column, without changing direction. When a player moves a tower can carry as many coins as he wants to the target cell, but he must leave at least one coin in the origin cell. The target cell must be empty and in his movement the tower cannot jump over other towers or other coins. Every move will create new towers, which can be moved in next turns. A tower consists of at least two coins. A coin on a cell cannot move, but can block the movement of other towers.

The game ends when a player on his turn cannot move a tower. The player who made the last move is the winner of the game.

item.description:
"Baaa~~~!" 
In Baaatle Sheep, players take turns to roll two dice and choose an action from the 5 x 5 grid on game map. You may plant new grass in your backyard, eat grass from your opponent's lawn, perform some acrobatic action to earn rewards, or even learn new tricks to out-smart your opponent! Once you have planted enough grass, or eaten up your opponent's lawn, you become the winner in Baaatle Sheep!

GYÜMI Géniusz (FRUTTA! Genius or GYUMI Genius) is well known and funny memory card game for 9-12 years kids and the adults.

It's more special, more cheerful, than original GYÜMI. The goal is same: The player who collects the highest number of points using their excellent memory skills will be the winner! But the Genius is more difficult, because values of fruits in the deck are different distribution.

It's a GYÜMI (FRUTTA! Kids or FRUIT MIX) variant, that more special, more cheerful.

More fruit, more points and more possibilities!

name.value: Doug The Bluffscouts' Adventure 3-D Board Game

item.description:
It's the Great Wilderness Adventure - and you're invited! So grab your backpack, and join Doug and the other Bluffscouts on their mountain-top camping trip.

Hike up and down the 3-D mountain trails collecting the gear you need for your campsite - firewood, water, a tent. Then hunt for the special badge that's yours and yours alone: Doug's sister Judy needs to find her Bongo Drums... Roger needs to find Stinky the Cat. Good ole' Doug may stumple along and help you find your gear. Or you might send out that canine camper Porkchop to swipe what you need from another campsite. Be the first Bluffscout to set up your camp - and win Doug's Great Wilderness Adventure Game!

What Is It?
Girls’ Night StoryClub is a reinvention of girls’ night in. Actually, it’s so fun it feels more like a girls’ night out! You know Mad Libs? Where the story is written and you fill in the noun, adjective, verb, etc. and you have this funny story? Well Girls’ Night is just the opposite. A ‘Sex and the City’ saucy kinda opposite. We give you a Storybook and Story Starters, People, Places and Things cards for you and and your friends to create one helluva crazy adventure. It’s a girls’ night like you’ve never experienced filled with laughter, connection and creativity.

“Funny, Unpredictable and Unexpectedly Outrageous!”

The Game:
Girls’ Night can spice up any girls’ night in, book club, wine club, dinner party, supper club, or moms’ group. The game can also be customized for a special event activity to shake up networking groups, writing groups, company retreats and women’s conferences. Girls’ Night creates better connections, creative thinking and laughter—the perfect recipe to kick any gathering into high gear. You never know where the story will go! Oh, and FYI, the guys love playing too!

ALEWOOD is a bounty hunting strategy drinking game that takes place in the wild west! It is a bold strategy drinking game that NEVER forces players to drink as a punishment. Enjoy your high proof craft beer and as you sip your beverage the descending drink line in your pint glass will change how you play the game.

Outlaws have overrun the town of Alewood holding its citizens in a grip of terror. But when the citizens learn about the bounty on each outlaw's head... they "heroically" spring into action, banding together to take back their home! Sharing the danger but never the glory... nor the bounty.

In Alewood, your pint in your pistol. Drink to alter your shooting speed, play skill cards to forge your reputation and discard your hand to unleash a barrage of bullets and capture multiple outlaws. But watch out! These outlaws won't go down without a fight. Surprise attacks and unique abilities will keep each game unpredictable and competitive. Your fellow players can also play hinder cards onto you. Tarnishing your reputation and giving you outlandish prompts to perform during the game. If you fail to perform your hinders, you will be forced to discard - effectively making it harder for you to capture outlaws during shootouts.

WITNESS your reputation change throughout the game!

WATCH your friends act ridiculous just to keep their cards!

PUNISH your opponents for not acting silly enough!

GAIN permanent upgrades when you finish your pint. Never drink as a punishment!

A game accessible for drinkers and players of every type, including non-alcoholic! Seriously, this game works great even with a glass of apple juice :)

item.description:
Experience a real adventure in the African savannah and find out if you are the king of the herd, but beware! in your wild world lurking dangers and unexpected traps that would change the course of your adventure.

Safari Sabana is the first game of the brand and the first of its kind, is a game where stealth is the key to win, fast and fun collect all the animals of the herd before your opponents. Set in the sunny Africam savanna and features artwork that takes you to the wild world where you can show if have what it needs to be the king !!

You can play fron 2 until 8 player and from 7 years old up to top, its easy to play so you can play it anywhere you want, its small to fit in your poket.

Make sure you have always 3 cards in your hand, every movement you do always keep 3 cards in hands, attack the opponent's animal to collect it in your own deck or defend others opponent's attaks to draw the animal. The first one who collect the 5 animals of a same herd wins.

From the ashes of war, nations rise to power in the atomic age. Each player takes control of a nation struggling for power in the latter part of the 20th century. They build up their nation’s industry, commerce, and government by acquiring resources, building structures, and tapping sources of energy. The price of oil is going up, and nuclear energy is the wave of the future. The Manhattan Project: Energy Empire is set in the same "universe" as The Manhattan Project, but it's a standalone game, not an expansion.

The major threat in Energy Empire is not war, but uncertain global impacts, that result from side effects of industrialization and pollution. Many actions come with a cost. So, as nations become more industrious, they also increase the amount of pollution in the environment. Careful use of science can mitigate the harmful effects of industry, and can also help avert global crises.

Energy Empire uses worker placement, tableau-building, and resource management mechanics. On each turn, a player can choose to either work or generate. On a work turn, a player plays a single worker on the main board, then uses workers and energy to activate cards in their tableau. Players may spend energy to use an occupied space on the main board, so no spaces are ever completely blocked. On a generate turn, players get to renew their supply of energy by rolling "energy dice" that represent nuclear, coal, oil, solar, and other forms of energy.

link.value: The Manhattan Project: Energy Empire – Cold War
The Manhattan Project: Energy Empire – Mexico
The Manhattan Project: Energy Empire – Missile Crisis

item.description:
The Candy Man is a Symbol Matching, Set Building Strategy game for all ages.

In this game, each player has a hand of ingredient cards. In the middle of the table, there are five recipe cards, which show different ingredients. Players take turns drawing new ingredients and playing ingredients on the recipe. On their turn, players can either play one ingredient on a recipe, or play all missing ingredients on a recipe. If a player plays the last missing ingredient, he scores that recipe, and it is replaced by a new recipe. Play continues until a player reaches 100 points.

The game has different game modes. The basic game is aimed at younger players, and allows them to focus on the symbol matching. The other game modes add Golden Ticket cards to the game, which are special actions that are rewarded randomly, and Role Cards, which give the players different special powers.

Math Kings is a collection of fun math's games in one box!

Classic Mode
Played on the board side with numbers. Classic Mode can be considered a Math's version of scrabble. The extra numbers on the board once used add to your points score for your sum.

Almost Countdown
A guide for the dice order Left to right is indicated on the back of the game manual. Players have to make a sum to match the dice roll amount (1-7 D6 Dice). Can be played against the timer. Players sums are hidden behind screens and only revealed once all players have made the sum or the time has ran out.

Advanced Sum up
Players have to use the shards to display the sum total. Players sums are hidden behind screens and only revealed once all players have made the sum or the time has ran out.

Pure Brain Power
Played on the board side with no numbers. Pure Brain Power eliminates any extra points from numbers on the board and comes down to pure math's. This mode is for you uber math's people out there.

Each Anno Domini set consists of 336 cards, with a description of a historical event on one side of the card, and the year (and sometimes specific date) in which it happened on the other. Each player receives nine of these cards (or less, if you want the game to be shorter), and may only look at the descriptions. Players then put in turn a card on the table, *trying* to put theirs in chronological order. A player may, instead of adding a card, claim that the order in which the cards were put is incorrect. In this case all cards are turned over and the correct years revealed. If the order was correct then the doubting player receives two cards and skips a turn. If the order was incorrect then the previous player, who accepted the order as correct, receives three cards. The first player that gets rid of all the cards wins.

Bluffing is as least as important as knowledge in this game. Most events are rather obscure or are hard to date exactly, so this ain’t no game for the nerds/geeks of this world, even they might think so, because it’s full of surprises and pure fun. Highly recommended, because Anno Domini is a blast to play, is a very enjoyable social event and you even learn something from it.

The set, for the Italian market, Scienza e Natura contains historical events which are related to science and nature discoveries and strangeness. Like all Anno Domini the Scienza e Natura edition can be played as standalone or mixed with some or even all editions.

Anno Domini Scienza e Natura is a functional merger of two previous set themes, Nature and Wissenschaft & Forschung.

From the website:

5150: Urban Renewal is our Sci-Fi RPG. Players adventure in and around New Hope City gaining Fame and Fortune while increasing their abilities. NHC is a complete Blade Runnereque urban environment inhabited by over 50 professions, with humans and aliens alike.

The game includes a low bookkeeping complete campaign system to link your adventures and track your progress. Urban Renewal generates your adventures with no two ever being the same!

Urban Renewal is playable solo, cooperatively and competitively, head to head and playable with any figures in any scale

Urban Renewal is the core rules for a long line of supplements to follow, starting with our first, New Hope City PI.



A sandbox style game, play a one-off standard miniatures game with your opponent on one side of a city block as a group of gangers and yours on the other as the police and have at! (Or step things up and include cybernetics and "Cyndees" and smuggled Star Army weapons to add to the carnage) Last man standing wins!Add Attributes and skills to make the game more RPG-like, letting your figures advance between games, adding more goals like finding lost technology, raiding corporate headquarters or simply going gambling for an evening and making it out of the casino alive!

Several pre-made scenarios are included in the book allowing you to customize your games to the complexity you desire.

Use whatever miniatures you have around!

If you liked 5150:Star Army, this merely takes that world and narrows the focus down to 1 figure and one city.

Objective: be the first reaching target space '75'
- simple 'Roll & Move' game/ moving by turns -
each player moves his/her meeple according die roll
ending on a red marked space follow instructions...

Welcome to the world of Doki Doki Love!. Love is in the air and it is your job to help your Hero find that special person in their life. Things aren’t as simple as that though, oh no, this world is full of all the Anime tropes you’ve come to know over the years. Tropes are elements that appear in multiple creative works, so if you watch Anime, you will know lots of the tropes that are used. Can you help the General Protagonist end up with the Girl Next Door? Or will the obsessive Yandere try to keep them apart? Maybe you’re lucky and the Yandere isn’t interested in you, but you still need to worry about your Rival getting in your way, along with all the other guys trying to get the Girl Next Door’s attention.

Heroes and Love Interests are drawn randomly, so each time you play Doki Doki Love!, you will have to find the best way to make you Hero appeal to the various Love Interests. While it may seem easy to just increase your Appeal and Encounter a Love Interest, be warned that it is not. Other Heroes will try to lower your Appeal and get in your way. Who said love was simple? You must fight with all your soul to end up with the person you want! And don’t worry, you can mess up their plans as well.

The base set for Doki Doki Love! contains tropes found in slice of life, romance/comedy, and school Anime. Do not fret though! There are plenty tropes in all kinds of Anime, so maybe (hopefully) there will be new ones coming in the future… And don’t worry if you don’t know many tropes, you will learn more after playing this game.

Oh, and this game is about Anime and love, so you know some Ecchi elements will find their way into the game.

Story:
Under the sea, eight fighters are ready to fight for their lives. So, pick up your card to join this fight, develop your strategy to eat others’ fishes and raise your score.
The victory shall be yours!
Warning: Don’t think too complicated, otherwise you may gain nothing but laughter.


Introduction:
This is an exciting and easy game. In each round, all you have to do is play one card, execute its ability and calculate your points. 
So, think hard and play your cards at the right time. Your little Krill will knock down others big Shark!

Be the first, who visits all ten numbered points, avoiding major mistakes.

Players choose any starting point. Then, they take turns, rolling the die and following the streets/roads in recommended directions. Players should consider all traffic signs - mistakes will lead to penalties. 
 Likely published late 1950s.

Centuries is a card drafting, deck building card game.

Taking place during the turbulent but exciting Renaissance, players take on the role of a leader of a city of Renaissance Europe. Players try to construct a Major Construction within their city, collect resources, expand the their treasuries, enlarge armies, develop technology, build structures, establish trade, and colonize the world, sometimes with the help of notables like Leonardo DaVinci or Queen Elizabeth. Be the Leader who exceeds what other Leaders can do and become victorious!

Played in three Centuries, players collect resource cards in order to afford other cards that in turn award the player with victory points. A key mechanic involves deciding which cards to pass to the other Players and which to keep in a modest supply deck. Modular in nature, Players can play from 3 - 6 modules. With the 3 module game, a fun and fairly short game can be enjoyed even by novice players. With the full game, Players enjoy a challenging game that will stretch the skills of the most hardened strategist.

Cards are lavishly decorated with the great works of art from the Renaissance and can be played in multiple ways: either in a basic manner or with an added bonus, played to build the major construction, passed, kept to enlarge the supply deck, or discarded for money.

Centuries is a fast-paced, strategy card game with limitless replayability with no game playing exactly the same.

link.value: Card Games: Draw and Discard Games

item.description:
Wolf In The Fold is a game of tile placement and cooperation. The wolf pack is on the hunt, and they want your herd. Build fences and hire shepherds to protect your flock. If the wolves eat more sheep than you can round up, you lose the game!

Simple rules make Wolf in the Fold fun for younger children, but this game is not suitable for very small children who may choke on the game tiles.

Treasure Tomb is a game of strategic tile-laying, dice-rolling, and card collecting. Players lay tiles to construct pathways through the mummy's tomb. Draw a treasure card when you pass a treasure token or place the mummy when you land on a sarcophagus token. Treasure cards can be either event cards or gold. Place the gold in a face-up pile near you. The first person to collect 50 gold wins the game.

But beware! Others may steal your gold with event cards or boot you from the maze.

A German card game played with the 32-card deck composed of the values seven through ace in the four suits. This game is a simplified version of the German game Skat - in that the trumps are fixed (always hearts), but the ranking is still the same:
A-10-K-Q-J-9-8-7.

Depending on how many players you have, you reduce the 32 card deck further.




 
 Players

 Cards In Deck

 # Dealt to each player

 
 
 5

 32 (7 -> A)

 6

 
 
 4

 30 (remove 7♥ & 7♦)

 7

 
 
 3

 26 (remove all 7's + 8♥ & 8♦)

 8

 
 
 2

 20 (10 -> A)

 9

 


Players take turns after dealing to see if they want to make a go of a play. Goal of making a go at it is to get 66 or more points in the tricks you capture. If you make 66, you get your wager (fixed, say 1 pt). If you make a go and fail to get 66 pts you loose 2x wager (say -2 pts). If you make a go and fail to get more than 33, you loose 4x the wager (say -8 pts). If you make a go and succeed and keep the sum of everyone else to 33 or below, you win 3x the wager (say 3 pts).

The points are: A=11, 10=10, K=4, Q=3, J=2, and 7,8,9 =0.
So there are 120 points on offer, and you need to capture 66 of them. Remember the 10 is better than the king, and there are rules for using trumps and playing trumps and suits - so if you don't think you can make it, pass the option to make a play to the next person. If the question to play goes around the table fully and no one takes it, its a bust and reshuffle ( There is no Skat like option of playing with a crappy hand).

Once cards are dealt there will be 2 cards left over - leave those face down. Whomever makes a play, gets to draw those 2 card into their hand and discard 2 cards, to set aside. Those set-aside cards count in the scoring of the player making a play. So its important what you discard - consider the rules of when suits and trumps need to be played.

First player left of the dealer plays first card (regardless of who decided to make a go of it this hand). You have to play the suit led with, if you have it. If you don't have it, but have hearts, you must trump with a heart (your choice which). If you don't have hearts either, play any card - but you won't get that trick. If hearts is the first card played, you MUST play hearts if you have it and you MUST play a higher heart if you can.

This way, you can see that its possible to force others to play hearts at certain times and get the trump cards out of play, and then still control play and be able to bring home points with less valuable cards like face-cards.

It sounds very complex, but its not nearly as bad as it seems, and a great light version of Skat. Unlike Skat that requires exactly 3 players, this plays with 2-5 players.

The world is flooding, and it is your job to build the biggest, happiest, most populous fleet for humanity to survive on.

Players roll and draft dice to gain the resources they need to build various types of ships to add to their fleet, and to fend off regularly occurring storms.

Players score points by building ships, upgrading ships, increasing population, and having high morale.

The railway building farmpocalypse game!

Players place workers and play cards to take actions, which include farming (gathering resources), laying rails, delivering goods to cities, and combating zombie infestations.

Generally, a player plays one card per turn, which stays discarded until the player takes a Recover action. Recovering lets a player get all of their cards back, but it also causes zombies to spread. Zombies block cities from being delivered to, and also occupy worker slots, preventing players from getting supplies.

You are a half-blood between vampire and werewolf. You have power! You can be a vampire! A werewolf! A human! You are one of the most powerful creatures in history — but you were too powerful. All humans, vampires and werewolves are now searching for you to kill. You lost your home, parents, friends, everything by them. There is nothing left except bloody revenge.

The Night of Horror Dice is a simple dice game. You have three health points for each turn. First, choose your ability. You can use one ability from human, vampire and werewolf. Each abilities has unique effects. Then, pick up three enemy dices from pouch and throw. As the result you gain or lose your health, catch them or they might runaway. You can throw another three dices or stop your revenge. All your captured enemies are your score. Strong enemy gives more score. If you caught four or more enemies in a type, you got additional score. Careful about your health, and catch enemies as many as possible.

item.description:
Since the beginning of time, two opposing forces have been the pillars of the universe and coexist in eternal balance. Our Goddess in her infinite wisdom has sent a group of Overseers to protect our world. They have the power to bend human traits to their will, and they will always battle between each other to create the perfect symmetry between virtues and vices of humankind. You will now choose whether to find the best balance — or completely crush it for your own good.

Overseers is a drafting and bluffing game with a twist. Each player represents an Overseer whose objective is to bend traits in their favor to create the most dominant combination of virtues and vices. The game has three main phases:

1] Drafting: Each player receives six cards at random from the deck, selects one of them, then passes the rest to the player sitting on their left. The goal is to build up the combination that will grant them the most victory points. Some cards grant points on their own, while others require the same type of cards to earn more points.

2] Judgement: All players place their five trait cards in front of them in two rows: two face down and three face up to show the cards they chose. Give the information available, the Overseers then discuss which player has the strongest possible combination. After deliberating, players vote for this person using their token. The chosen player must then admit or deny the verdict:

— If they admit having the strongest combination, they must then discard two cards from their combination.
— If they deny this, the showdown phase happens, with all players revealing their scores. If the chosen player has the strongest combination, they lose the two cards that grant the most points; if not, instead they take one additional card of their choice from the discard pile.

3] Scoring: Each player shows all cards in front of them, then calculates their score.

The game might have other phases depending on the type of overseers being played as each character has special abilities that can change the outcome of the game, such as being able to peek at another player's hidden cards, steal a card before the scoring phase, or transform one card into another.

At the end of each round, players secret their victory point (VP) tokens to keep their score secret, and after three rounds whoever has the most VPs wins.

item.description:
Corsica is a fan-designed strategic board game for 4 players based on Lewis E. Pulsipher's Britannia.

In a typical game of Corsica, during 16 game rounds players will take command of the different nations that invaded and partially or fully controlled the island between 556 b.C., when the Ancient Greeks first settled the spot of Aleria, and 1796 a.D., when the island definitelly fell under French control. Therefore, nations available in Corsica include the autochthonous Corsican Ancient tribes (3 each player), Greeks, Carthagenese, Etrurians, Romans, Vandals, Ostrogoths, Byzantines, Sarracenes, Lombards, Franks, Aragonese, Vatican State, Pisan, Tuscan, Genoese, modern Corse people (2 different factions), Ottoman, English and French.

Furthermore, Corsica comes with and expansion that adds the II World War conflict to the original game, and a 17th game round.

Invasions take place at the beginning of each game round, and the goal for each player will be to first invade the island and then try to hold control of it fighting the new invaders as long as possible, while trying to accomplish his own nation's objetives.

While trying to stick as much as possible to the original game of Britannia, this new version has undergone some minor and major changes in order to addapt the gameplay and game feeling to this new Mediterranean context:

A typical game round of Corsica consists of the following phases: The invasion phase (in which the new invaders attack and settle the island), the diplomacy phase (in which nations can seal up to 4 pacts for the current game round), the internal struggle phase (in which all nations settled on Corsica fight each other), and during punctuation game rounds the punctuation phase.

Cavalry has been removed from the game, as Corsican geography makes it useless, but fleets and sea combat have been enabled, as historically the control of the waters around Corsica has been of great influence. Other concepts like roads, fortifications or watchtowers have been added, and as the island is much smaller than Britannia, movement (both land and sea) has been eased, maybe resulting in a more dynamic game experience.

Corsica is well known to European tourists for the beauty and quietness of its coasts and inlands. But what visitors may not know, is that on the same beaches where they do bath today, blood-thirsty, fierce warriors of all nations around the Mediterranean Sea have been landing during centuries with an only idea on their minds: taking full control of the island!

Be welcome to Corsica: a game that portraits the history of a 1500 years long conflict.

name.value: The Little Prince: Rising to the Stars
Le Petit Prince: Voyage vers les étoiles
Il Piccolo Principe: Verso le Stelle
Ο Μικρός Πρίγκιπας: Ταξίδι στα Άστρα

item.description:
In the Little Girl's wake, go to meet the Little Prince, flying on board your biplane! Flying from cloud to cloud and from surprise to surprise searching precious stars, an unexpected journey awaits.

The Little Prince: Rising to the Stars brings you in a journey from the Grandfather's house to the Little Prince's planet. It is a point-to-point movement game, in which your goal is to collect stars.

You move your plane by playing one of the fox cards in your hand, and every player starts with the same set of cards (eight cards numbered 1-5, with duplicates of 2, 3 and 4). Whoever is farthest back on the path to the Little Prince's planet is the active player, and this player plays one card from hand, moving at least one cloud and up to the number of clouds shown on the card. If you land on a star cloud, you take a star from the reserve; if you land on a telescope cloud, you flip one of the tokens at Grandfather's house to see what happens; if you land on a bird cloud, you take one card from Grandfather's deck, which provide different types of movement. If you arrive on a cloud where an opponent's plane sits, you take a card at random from that opponent's hand and give him in return a card of your choice.

When you cross one of the three connecting boards, you take one of the story tiles next to it, with these tiles holding 1-5 stars. Collect both the fox and Little Prince, and you earn eight stars for this pair instead of only two.

If you manage to make it all the way to the Little Prince's planet — and you'll need to pick up extra movement cards in order to do so — you receive a star-filled paper plane, with the quickest players receiving the most stars. In the end, whoever collects the most stars wins.

item.description:
From the publisher:

Assassinorum: Execution Force gives four Imperial Assassins an incredibly important mission - slay Chaos Lord Drask before his dark ritual brings about the end of the Imperium itself! A fast-paced co-operative game for one to four players, it blends stealth, tactics, subtle forward-thinking and outright blazing violence into a fantastic, tense, action-packed experience that is accessible to board game players of any level.
It contains everything you need to play to defeat the Chaos Space Marines Sorcerer.

Included in the box are four beautiful, exclusive Imperial Assassin miniatures - the Vindicare Assassin, armed with an Exitus Rifle and pistol, clad in a stealth suit; the Callidus Assassin, wielding a C’tan Phase sword, neural shredder and poison blades; the Eversor Assassin, with Executioner pistol and Neuro Gauntlet and the Culexus Assassin, with his psyk-out grenades. On top of these, you get fifteen Chaos Cultists, three Chaos Space Marines, a Chaos Familiar and a Chaos Space Marine Terminator Sorcerer.

On top of these incredible miniatures, there’s a set of detailed board tiles on heavy card stock, a deck of Event Cards, counters for various events in different shapes, sizes and designs and included dice.

item.description: In Tree, players raise trees from seedlings to majestic oaks, by combining various stages of root and treetop cards. But as players nurture life, they must also destroy it – by breaking, burning, or harvesting their opponent’s trees. By growth, or by destruction – players fight for victory points, or to outlast their opponents and hold the last living tree.

From their own land and time, Mulan, Lu Bu, and Musashi were transported to an arena to fight heroes from other places in a cruel game of survival. This was a fairy-tale place of terrible cruelty and fantastic legends. But then one day they found themselves elsewhere again, in a world called Yashima. This time they were joined by another hero of legend, Bruce Lee. Together they find themselves in a new world, and unlike the kami masters native to this land, their battle is in the hopes that each encounter may give them a clue on how they may return home.

Yashima: Legends from Fairytale is both a standalone two-player game as well as an expansion for Yashima: Legend of the Kami Masters that allows you to add two additional players to that base game. Combine these two items with Yashima: Legend of the Deep Woods and Yashima: Legends of the Icy Peaks for epic eight-player team-based showdowns!


 Play as Lu Bu to shock and awe opponents with raw power and a cavalier attitude towards your allies. 
 Play as Bruce Lee to counter your opponent's attacks, turning their offense into yours. 
 Play as Musashi to use unmatched agility and blur the lines between movement and strikes. 
 Play as Mulan to exploit your opponent's weaknesses with indirect tactics and redirect their own skills against them.

link.value: Yashima: Legend of the Kami Masters

item.description: Retro Raygun is a fast-paced miniature combat game set in the retro sci-fi future of the 24th Century. The brave Galacteers fight to protect mankind from sinister forces, while the domineering Valkeeri seek to enslave humanity. Led by the Robot Queen, the unstoppable Robot Legion plots the destruction of all living organisms. This 102 page, full-colour book contains the full game rules along with complete force lists for the Galacteers, Robot Legion, and the Valkeeri. The rules include 6 objective-based scenarios that encourage tactical decision making and narrative campaigns. The book also contains a Galactic Bestiary so you can include alien creatures like the dreaded Aquaclops and the voracious Slishians in your games.

Human Interface: Nakamura Tower (HINT) is a board game that is a unique combination of many elements known from tactical and skirmish games, RPGs and board games. The game is based on a struggle between two powerful megacorporations that takes place in the title tower.

HINT is designed for 2+ people but through different scenarios can be played alone, in cooperation or against other players. The story happens in the near future when the world is dominated by new technologies.

In HINT you will lead a team of selected professionals of a given faction. Each of them has unique skills and abilities, each one can be given weapons and other equipment, be enhanced genetically or cybernetically. All characteristics and modifiers are presented on special character and equipment cards (you don’t need to constantly flick through the rulebook). Each character card has a limited amount of slots that can be filled with equipment and modifications. The player can purchase additional equipment to replace the current item depending on the “group’s assets”. You may like your heroes or hate them but they will no longer be just anonymous pawns.

The game is played on a board showing the interior of the Nakamura corporate tower that is under attack by its rivals. The characters are moved using spaces on the board. This eliminates the need to measure distance when moving and fighting thus quickening the pace of the game and allowing to avoid misunderstandings. Each space presents a specific tactical situation that influences the characters placed on it.

Game mechanics are fairly easy as we wanted to achieve a perfect balance between a fun game and rules that enable a lot of tactical possibilities. The basic rules are easy to learn but the possibilities of their use grow significantly in combination with the characters’ skills and capabilities of equipment. The characters are defined by their basic physical and mental abilities and modifiers, which make it easier or more difficult to perform some tasks, that make them unique. These modifiers result from their skills, special training or cyberations and other equipment. The rules do not use any dice and the testing mechanics are based on cards that we call CanDo. The description on the card, its value and colour influence the final result of the test. The numerical value also states the location of a hit and additional effects connected to it.

item.description:
From the back of the box (translated):
"Build the most powerful themepark that you've ever seen. In Pretpark Tycoon you stand at the helm of your own amusement park. Build 3D attractions and attract many visitors. Groups of people walk through your park. If they visit your attraction, you earn fun chips. The player who earns most fun chips, wins the game. Pretpark Tycoon. The ride of your life!"

Pretpark Tycoon is a Monopoly-like/Hotels-like simplified children's game. Players buy and expand attractions with in-game money. Money is earned via Chance-cards or by exchanging fun chips for money. Fun chips are collected when visitors stop at your attraction. The first player to collect a certain number of fun chips, wins.

Players have no personal token on the gameboard. Four visitor group tokens move in one direction in the park. After your 'dice roll' (with a spinner) you decide which of the visitor groups you will move to reach your goal:


 to a spot where you can buy or expand an attractions, 
 to a spot with an attraction you own to earn fun chips, 
 to a spot where you get a Chance-card, 
 or simply to a spot to pass the attraction of the other players so they won't collect fun chips.


From the back of the box (in Dutch):
Bouw het machtigste pretpark dat je ooit hebt gezien. In Pretpark Tycoon sta je aan het roer van je eigen pretpark. Bouw 3D attracties en trek zoveel mogelijk bezoekers. Groepjes mensen lopen door je pretpark. Bezoeken ze jouw attractie, dan verdien je pretfiches. De Tycoon met de mooiste attracties die de meeste bezoekers trekt, wint het spel. Pretpark Tycoon. De rit van je leven!

Designer : Julien SENTIS
Artist : Boris MONCEL
Rulewriter : Jérémie VUILLARD
Publisher : Jonathan BIZET

Become the Master of Islands:
Discover unknow lands in the ocean. Conquer islands or block your opponent's expansion. Reload.

item.description:
Indoor target game. 
Each player in turn will take the plastic rings and try to throw them over the Walt Disney characters. Most successes wins.

likely published lste 1950s
similar in concept to Noddy's Ring Game - product code 36222

The Salmon Life Cycle Game follows the adventures of a salmon as it grows and travels from freshwater to the ocean, then back to its' birthplace stream. Each fish encounters dangers growing to adulthood. Players learn how few salmon actually return to their birthplace to spawn and reproduce and some of the many hazards they face as they complete their life cycle.

Up to six individuals may play the game, or two to six teams with two or more players per team.

Players or teams collect and lose "energy tokens," representing how salmon feed, grow, and lose energy in a daily struggle for life.

Players or teams have a reserve of fish lives. During the course of the game if they lose one of their lives they may cash in a fish life to continue play. This reinforces the concept of how many salmon die before they spawn.

Description from the publisher:

The Battle of Stalingrad (23 August 1942 - 2 February 1943) was a major battle of World War II in which Nazi Germany and its allies fought the Soviet Union for control of the city of Stalingrad in the southwestern Soviet Union.

Marked by constant close quarters combat and direct assaults on civilians by air raids, it is often regarded as the single largest and bloodiest battle in the history of warfare.

World War II: Stalingrad 1942-1943, part of the "Art of Tactic" line of games, allows players to recreate this battle. As with other games in this series, it can be played on its own or combined with any of the other titles. The game includes all of the models needed to play the scenarios in the box, but additional World War II mini kits in Zvezda's product line are fully compatible and can be used to expand the game with additional units.

link.value: World War II: Battle for Moscow, 1941
